To the right honorable my very singluar good Lord,

16 Martij
1590
. M
r

fol.248r
May it please yo
r
good L. I sent my last before
this the 10 of this moneth, wherein I made answear
to her
Ma
ties
letter of
e 1 and to divers of yo
r
L. of several dates. Howbeit in certaine pointes
I was driven untill this time to differ mine
answear: partly for that it required some lea-
sure, to use suche conference and inquirie, as
might satisfie her Ma
tie
partly also for that mine
answear depended upon
e resolution of this
Councel,
whiche I could not so speedely procure
as I would. We have often bin
together about
e affaires of
Ostend,
wherein
they have bin moved, as her Ma
tie
required, and
as earnestly as might be. But they againe are
as instant to have her Hig
nes
advertised, that
whatsoever shall be needefull for defense of
e
place, against
e sea or
e Enemie, shall be
carefully provided: and for
e accomplishing
therof they have written there unto their
officers, to certifie particularly howe every thing
doth stand. But they knowe no considera-
tion for w
ch
they should be induced, to streng-
then the towne w
t
2 companies more. For
they stand precisely upon it, that
e companies
there already, w
ch
are 8 at this present,
are more then are needefull. And
touching that w
ch
hath bin signified by the go-
verno
r
unto them, that
e
D. of Parma
is
bent and prepareth to surprise, or besiege, or
distresse it some way, they doe not understand
it to have any good grownde: and their
officers there in place, w
ch
never faile to in-
forme of every speciall occurrence, advertise
no suche mater. And albeit it were so, they
fol.248v
repute them selves well able to relieve it in
extremitie. The
Governo
r
, they thinke,
is therfore desirous to increase his nombers, that
he might make a better warre upon
e Enemies
contrey. But they on
e other side are per-
suaded, that although his exploites may somwhat
weaken
e Enemie, and thereby benefit
e con-
trey, yet any overthrowe
at may be given
to
e troupes,
at he shall send abroade, will
more endanger
e towne, and endommage their
estate, then all those litle warres can turne
to their good. There are yet besides some
other respectes, for w
ch
e Councel doth refuse,
to assent to his demand, as they themselves
will declare in their letters to her Ma
tie
.
I have also recommended unto them her Hig
nes
motion, for
e enlarging of his pay: wherein
they promise heereafter to doe somwhat as
ei
may, and as they see the contributions of those
quarters will stretche therunto. But as nowe,
they say, they are enforced, to husband all unto
e uttermost, to beare their necessary charges.
The present intertenment w
ch
is given unto
him is 40
li
a moneth, which is more then they
allowe, to any other governo
r
of any garrison
towne of theirs: excepting
Mons
r
Fauma
Governo
r
of
Hoesden,
who in consideration of
his charge, being General of
e Artillerie,
hath also 40
li
monethly, and no intertenm
e
t
for
at office. I can not learne
by inquirie, that there is other preparation of
shipping, by those of
Graveling,
Dunkerk,
or
Newport,
then hath bin usual heretofore. They
have bin busier of Late, and more abroade
fol.249r
then at any time in sommer, because
e shippes
of
e states are wont in Winter to returne, whiche
is
e time the others observe, to exercise their piracie,
But nowe
e season is againe, that
e states
doe enter into conference, about
e setting fourth
of their shippes: w
ch
time I doe attend to pro-
pose in their meeting her Ma
ties
pleasure.
That
e Enemie could prevaile, in stopping Ostend
haven by meanes of his shippping, it is not thought
by
Count Maurice
, or by any
at I have asked,
ether likely or possible. Because I
have seene that letter, w
ch
was lately written
to yo
r
L. from
S
r
Francis Vere
, wherein is certi-
fied in part, what is thought upon this sommer
to be exploited by
e states: and because it partly
belongeth to
S
r
John Norreis
report, to whome
the states in that mater have signified som-
what of their purpose, I will not troble yo
r
L.
w
t
a double rehersall. The just acccount
at
they have made, howsoever in publike they deli-
ver it otherwise, is to bring at lest into
e fielde
8000 foote, and 1800 horse. I have
made no mention heere as yet, of
e cause
at
was solicited by
e Deputies of
Flushing.
For
I have alwaies understood, that
e victuelles
of Flushing, to whom Cap
t
Wingfild
and
Ran-
dolphe
were indebted, have receaved long agoe,
some part of satisfaction of
e towne it self of
Flushing. How muche I am not certaine, but I
will endevo
r
by some meanes to knowe
e certaintie
and certifie yo
r
L. For as yet I am per-
suaded, that
e Deputies pretence in
e behalf of
the widowes, is a litle peece of cunning, to re-
cover that from her Ma
tie
whiche
e towne hath
disboursed. Howbeit if it falle out otherwise,
fol.249v
and as they have informed, I will present
e mater
to
e states, to be ended, in suche sort, as yo
r
L.
hath proposed. Yo
r
L. letter of
e
25 of Fe
b
w
ch
was consigned to
e towne of
Harwiche,
to be speedely sent hither, was brought
but yesterday unto me. The towne
of
Nieumeghen
is muche molested every day by
the sconce
at is before it, w
ch
we made
e last
sommer. They have deputed their governo
r
, two
Burgmasters, and 4 burghers, to shewe
e D. of
Parma, that unles w
t
a time, w
ch
they have limi-
ted unto him, they may be freed of
at fort, they
will presently fall in Treaty, w
t
e states of
those contreis. This is written to Count Maurice
from a frinde w
t
in
e towne.
Although in writing to yo
r
L. it may but ill
beseeme me, to preferre other causes, then are per-
tinent to my service: yet at
M
r
Gilpins
very
earnest request, I can not refuse in his behalf
to solicit yo
r
L. w
t
all humble intreaty, that
his late petition for succeeding his kinsman
John Gilpin
, may be heard w
t
suche favo
r
, as
ether yo
r
L. may vouchesafe of yo
r
self, or by
yo
r
honorable meanes may be easely procured.
Being greatly charged, w
t
a familie of chil-
dren; and having nothing in assurance, for
e
stay of his living, he is very carefull in minde
to provide himself of some estate. Howe well
he hath deserved for his painfull endevors in
her Ma
ties
buisnes, and also for hereafter howe
muche it may behoove, to have his service heere
continued, as no man can consider better then
yo
r
L. so I putt him in good comfort, that no
man will be readier to reward or recommend
him, when occasion is presented.
fol.150r
It is the opinion heere of many, and
e like is
advertised by divers out of
Brabant,
that
e D. of
Parma is staied for ether going himself, or sending
into
Fraunce.
For the newe supplie of succo
rs
,
at
shall be sent from
e
Pope,
and are to come out of
Spaine,
is thought enough to serve
e turne for
any purpose in France. And in that respect it
is reported, that these great preparations of the
Duke in these contreis, are wholy for
e warre,
that he is bent to make heere: and that his prin-
cipal designe is to besiege
Breda.
Notw
t
standing that answear, that I have given
to
e Councel, as yo
r
L. willed in yo
r
letter of
e
23 of Fe
b
they are suto
rs
once againe, that I
should move her Ma
tie
in their b ehalf for
e aug-
mentation of
e 4 horsebandes, that are heere in
her Hig
nes
pay, to
e nomber of a 120. They
are thorowly persuaded, that if her Hig
nes
would
referre it to their agreement w
t
e captaines,
they could take suche order, as they should all be
contented, as these contrey captaines have bin
already, to accept
e allowance of 20 shillinges
for every horse, and to have their armo
r
of
e
contrey, w
ch
shall be deducted upon their pay
in three monethes. Whereby they inferre
at
e whole for so litle space, as they demaund it,
w
ch
is but 6 or 7 monethes, will amount but
to
e summe of 700
li
sterling, or therabout.
Being very solemnly and earnestly intreated
to motion this againe, as a mater of
at nature,
that may greatly advance
e services towardes,
and growe in
e whole to a very smalle charge,
I leave it to yo
r
L. to be reported to her Hig
nes
and take my humble leave. From
e Hage
Marche 16 1590.
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley
